awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2021 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. 

The title of the project for this fellowship to Christian R. Gaetz  is " Combinatorics, Coxeter groups, and applications". The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Lauren Williams.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Below I summarize the significant progress made during my fellowship on the three main projects I originally proposed. 

Bruhat interval polytopes:
Polytopes are higher-dimensional generalizations of polygons. Bruhat interval polytopes are an important class of polytopes with connections to algebra, geometry, and combinatorics. I resolved the open questions about Bruhat interval polytopes included in my original Project Description and in so-doing resolved conjectures of Fraser, of Lee--Masuda, and of Lee--Masuda--Park. This work makes up the publication "On one-skeleton posets of Bruhat interval polytopes".


Maximum multiplicity of generators in reduced words:
Reduced words are ways of reversing the order of an ordered collection of objects by a sequence of swaps of the order of a consecutive pair of objects. Reduced words are important in algebra and combinatorics. A natural question about reduced words is: what is the largest number of times a given object can be part of a swap in a reduced word? In joint works with Gao, Nenashev, Pakawut, and Postnikov ("The maximum multiplicity of a generator in a reduced word" and "Repeatable patterns and the maximum multiplicity of a generator in a reduced word"), we investigate asymptotic answers to this question, making progress on another problem from my Project Description. We also draw new connections to the topic of "k-sets"; this topic is important in the analysis of certain geometric algorithms.


Balance constants for Coxeter groups:
I completed my project on balance constants for Coxeter groups, resulting in the publication "Balance constants for Coxeter groups". Balance constants measure how well one can sort a partially-sorted list of objects by making a single comparison between some pair of objects.  The study of balance constants has received considerable attention due to its implications for information-theoretic bounds on sorting algorithms. In my joint work in Gao, we discovered that this usual notion of balance constant corresponds in a certain way to the "symmetric group". We show that many results and conjectures about balance constants can be extended to Coxeter groups other than the symmetric group. This brings new techniques to bear in the study of balance constants.

 

I also mentored an undergraduate research project, resulting in the publication "Positivity of permutation pattern character polynomials".
